<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Citroën</h1>
<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>

</div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Citro%C3%ABn_Showroom_1,_Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es,_Paris_September_2013.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Citro%C3%ABn_Showroom_1%2C_Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es%2C_Paris_September_2013.jpg/220px-Citro%C3%ABn_Showroom_1%2C_Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es%2C_Paris_September_2013.jpg" width="220" height="336" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Citro%C3%ABn_Showroom_1%2C_Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es%2C_Paris_September_2013.jpg/330px-Citro%C3%ABn_Showroom_1%2C_Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es%2C_Paris_September_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Citro%C3%ABn_Showroom_1%2C_Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es%2C_Paris_September_2013.jpg/440px-Citro%C3%ABn_Showroom_1%2C_Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es%2C_Paris_September_2013.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3523" data-file-height="5380" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Citro%C3%ABn_Showroom_1,_Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es,_Paris_September_2013.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
C 42 is the Citroën showroom on the Champs Elysées in Paris</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><b>Citroën</b> (<small>French pronunciation:&#160;​</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA_for_French" title="Help:IPA for French">[si.tʁɔ.ˈɛn]</a></span>) is a major French automobile manufacturer, part of the <a href="/wiki/PSA_Peugeot_Citro%C3%ABn" class="mw-redirect" title="PSA Peugeot Citroën">PSA Peugeot Citroën</a> group since 1976. It was founded in 1919 by French industrialist <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Citro%C3%ABn" title="André Citroën">André-Gustave Citroën</a> (1878–1935).</p>
<p>In 1934, Citroën developed the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant" title="Citroën Traction Avant">Traction Avant</a>, not only the world's first mass-produced front-wheel drive car, but also one of the first cars to feature a <a href="/wiki/Vehicle_frame#Types" title="Vehicle frame">unitary</a>-type body, with no chassis frame holding the mechanical components.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 1954, Citroën produced the world's first <a href="/wiki/Hydropneumatic" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydropneumatic">hydropneumatic</a> <a href="/wiki/Self-levelling_suspension" title="Self-levelling suspension">self-levelling suspension</a> system,<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> then in 1955 the revolutionary <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS" title="Citroën DS">DS</a>, the first mass production car with modern <a href="/wiki/Disc_brakes" class="mw-redirect" title="Disc brakes">disc brakes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-vintagecars.about.com.2Finternet_archive_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vintagecars.about.com.2Finternet_archive-6">[6]</a></sup> In 1967, Citroën introduced <a href="/wiki/Headlamp#Beam_aim_control" title="Headlamp">swiveling headlights</a> in several models, allowing for greater visibility on winding roads. Citroën cars have received various international and national-level awards, including three <a href="/wiki/European_Car_of_the_Year" title="European Car of the Year">European Car of the Year</a>.</p>
<p>Citroën has a successful history in motorsport, and is the only automobile manufacturer to have won three different official championships from the <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A9d%C3%A9ration_Internationale_de_l%27Automobile" title="Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile">International Automobile Federation</a>: the World Rally Raid Championship (five times<sup id="cite_ref-Citro.C3.ABn_victories_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Citro.C3.ABn_victories-7">[7]</a></sup>), the <a href="/wiki/World_Rally_Championship" title="World Rally Championship">World Rally Championship</a> (eight times <sup id="cite_ref-Citro.C3.ABn_victories_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Citro.C3.ABn_victories-7">[7]</a></sup>), and the <a href="/wiki/World_Touring_Car_Championship" title="World Touring Car Championship">World Touring Car Championship</a>.</p>
<p>Citroën has been selling vehicles in <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> since 1984, and it represents a major market for the brand today, largely via the <a href="/wiki/Dongfeng_Peugeot-Citro%C3%ABn" title="Dongfeng Peugeot-Citroën">Dongfeng Peugeot-Citroën</a> joint venture. In 2014, when <a href="/wiki/PSA_Peugeot_Citro%C3%ABn" class="mw-redirect" title="PSA Peugeot Citroën">PSA Peugeot Citroën</a> ran into severe financial difficulties, the <a href="/wiki/Dongfeng_Motor" title="Dongfeng Motor">Dongfeng Motor</a> Corporation took an ownership stake.</p>
<p>The brand celebrated its 90th Anniversary in 2009. The Citroën's C_42 showroom, on the <a href="/wiki/Champs_Elys%C3%A9es" class="mw-redirect" title="Champs Elysées">Champs Elysées</a> in <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a>, is a place where Citroën organises some exhibitions, shows its cars and concept cars.</p>
<p></p>

</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-23"><a href="#Concept_cars"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Concept cars</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-24"><a href="#Logo"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Logo</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-25"><a href="#Factories"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Factories</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-26"><a href="#Current_product_lineup"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">Current product lineup</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-27"><a href="#Citro.C3.ABn"><span class="tocnumber">7.1</span> <span class="toctext">Citroën</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-28"><a href="#DS_line"><span class="tocnumber">7.2</span> <span class="toctext">DS line</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-29"><a href="#Dongfeng_Peugeot-Citro.C3.ABn_.28joint_venture.29"><span class="tocnumber">7.3</span> <span class="toctext">Dongfeng Peugeot-Citroën (joint venture)</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-30"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-31"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-32"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">9.1</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-33"><a href="#Bibliography"><span class="tocnumber">9.2</span> <span class="toctext">Bibliography</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-34"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<p></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_years">Early years</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Early years">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:142px;"><a href="/wiki/File:AndreCitroen_crop.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/AndreCitroen_crop.jpg/140px-AndreCitroen_crop.jpg" width="140" height="266" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/AndreCitroen_crop.jpg/210px-AndreCitroen_crop.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/AndreCitroen_crop.jpg/280px-AndreCitroen_crop.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1373" data-file-height="2612" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:AndreCitroen_crop.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
André Citroën</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:142px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tour_Eiffel_Citroen.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Tour_Eiffel_Citroen.jpg/140px-Tour_Eiffel_Citroen.jpg" width="140" height="202" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Tour_Eiffel_Citroen.jpg/210px-Tour_Eiffel_Citroen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Tour_Eiffel_Citroen.jpg/280px-Tour_Eiffel_Citroen.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="2890" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Tour_Eiffel_Citroen.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Eiffel_Tower" title="Eiffel Tower">Eiffel Tower</a> served as a billboard for Citroën from 1925 to 1934.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Citro%C3%ABn" title="André Citroën">André Citroën</a> built armaments for France during <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>; after the war, however, unless he planned ahead he knew he would have a modern factory without a product.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1920_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1920-8">[8]</a></sup> There was nothing automatic about the decision to become an automobile manufacturer once the war was finished, but the auto-business was one that Citroën knew well, thanks to a successful six-year stint working with <a href="/wiki/Mors_(automobile)" title="Mors (automobile)">Mors</a> between 1908 and the outbreak of <a href="/wiki/First_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="First World War">war</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1920_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1920-8">[8]</a></sup> The decision to switch to automobile manufacturing was evidently taken as early as 1916 which is when Citroën asked the engineer Louis Dufresne, previously with <a href="/wiki/Panhard" title="Panhard">Panhard</a>, to design a technically sophisticated 18HP automobile for which he could use his factory once peace broke out.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1920_8-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1920-8">[8]</a></sup> Long before that happened, however, he had modified his vision, and decided, (like <a href="/wiki/Henry_Ford" title="Henry Ford">Henry Ford</a>), that the best post war opportunities in auto-making would involve a lighter car of good quality, but made in sufficient quantities to be priced enticingly.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1920_8-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1920-8">[8]</a></sup> In February 1917 Citroën contacted another engineer, <a href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jules_Salomon" class="extiw" title="fr:Jules Salomon">Jules Salomon</a>, who already had a considerable reputation within the French automotive sector as the creator, in 1909, of a little car called <a href="/wiki/Le_Z%C3%A8bre" title="Le Zèbre">Le Zèbre</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1920_8-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1920-8">[8]</a></sup> André Citroën's mandate was characteristically demanding and characteristically simple: to produce an all-new design for a 10 HP car that would be better equipped, more robust and less costly to produce than any rival product at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1920_8-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1920-8">[8]</a></sup> The result was the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Type_A" title="Citroën Type A">Type A</a>, announced to the press, just four months after <a href="/wiki/Armistice_with_Germany" class="mw-redirect" title="Armistice with Germany">the guns fell silent</a>, in March 1919.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1920_8-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1920-8">[8]</a></sup> The first "production" Type A emerged from the factory at the end of May, and in June it was exhibited at a show room in the <a href="/wiki/Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es" title="Champs-Élysées">Champs-Élysées</a> which normally sold <a href="/wiki/Alda_(automobile)" title="Alda (automobile)">Alda cars</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1920_8-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1920-8">[8]</a></sup> Citroën persuaded the owner of the Alda business, <a href="/wiki/Fernand_Charron" title="Fernand Charron">Fernand Charron</a>, to lend him the show-room (just as a few years later Charron would be persuaded to become a major investor in Citroën business).<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1920_8-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1920-8">[8]</a></sup> On 7 July 1919, the first customer took delivery of a new <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Type_A" title="Citroën Type A">Citroën 10HP "Type A"</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1920_8-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1920-8">[8]</a></sup></p>
<p>That same year, André Citroën briefly negotiated with <a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">General Motors</a> on a proposed sale of the Citroën company to GM.<sup id="cite_ref-Sloan1964p317_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sloan1964p317-9">[9]</a></sup> The deal nearly closed, but GM ultimately decided that its management and capital would be too overstretched by the takeover.<sup id="cite_ref-Sloan1964p317_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sloan1964p317-9">[9]</a></sup> thus Citroën remained independent till 1935.</p>
<p>Citroën was a keen marketer—he used the <a href="/wiki/Eiffel_Tower" title="Eiffel Tower">Eiffel Tower</a> as the world's largest advertising sign, as recorded in <i><a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Records" title="Guinness World Records">Guinness World Records</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> He also sponsored expeditions in Asia (Croisière Jaune), North America, (Croisière Blanche) and Africa (Croisière Noire) intended to demonstrate the potential for motor vehicles equipped with the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%A9gresse_track" title="Kégresse track">Kégresse track</a> system to cross inhospitable regions. The expeditions conveyed <a href="/wiki/Scientists" class="mw-redirect" title="Scientists">scientists</a> and <a href="/wiki/Journalists" class="mw-redirect" title="Journalists">journalists</a>.</p>
<div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:627px;max-width:627px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:177px;max-width:177px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Citroen_A_8_CV_Torpedo_1919.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Citroen_A_8_CV_Torpedo_1919.jpg/175px-Citroen_A_8_CV_Torpedo_1919.jpg" width="175" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Citroen_A_8_CV_Torpedo_1919.jpg/263px-Citroen_A_8_CV_Torpedo_1919.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Citroen_A_8_CV_Torpedo_1919.jpg/350px-Citroen_A_8_CV_Torpedo_1919.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="610" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">1919 <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Type_A" title="Citroën Type A">Citroën A 8CV Torpedo</a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:207px;max-width:207px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Citroen_B2_Torpedo_1921.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Citroen_B2_Torpedo_1921.jpg/205px-Citroen_B2_Torpedo_1921.jpg" width="205" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Citroen_B2_Torpedo_1921.jpg/308px-Citroen_B2_Torpedo_1921.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Citroen_B2_Torpedo_1921.jpg/410px-Citroen_B2_Torpedo_1921.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="519" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">1921 <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Type_B2" title="Citroën Type B2">Citroën B Torpedo</a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:237px;max-width:237px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Citroen_5_CV_Typ_C2_Torpedo_1923.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Citroen_5_CV_Typ_C2_Torpedo_1923.jpg/235px-Citroen_5_CV_Typ_C2_Torpedo_1923.jpg" width="235" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Citroen_5_CV_Typ_C2_Torpedo_1923.jpg/353px-Citroen_5_CV_Typ_C2_Torpedo_1923.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Citroen_5_CV_Typ_C2_Torpedo_1923.jpg/470px-Citroen_5_CV_Typ_C2_Torpedo_1923.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="452" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">1923 "Type C" 5CV</div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Demonstrating extraordinary toughness, a 1923 Citroën that had already travelled 48,000&#160;km (30,000&#160;mi) was the first car to be driven around Australia. The car, a 1923 Citroën 5CV Type C Torpedo, was driven by Neville Westwood from <a href="/wiki/Perth" title="Perth">Perth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_Australia" title="Western Australia">Western Australia</a>, on a round trip from August to December 1925. The car is now fully restored and in the collection of the <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Australia" title="National Museum of Australia">National Museum of Australia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 1924, Citroën began a business relationship with American engineer <a href="/wiki/Edward_G._Budd" title="Edward G. Budd">Edward G. Budd</a>. From 1899, Budd had worked to develop stainless steel bodies for railroad cars, for the <a href="/wiki/Pullman_Company" title="Pullman Company">Pullman</a> in particular. Budd went on to manufacture steel bodies for many automakers, <a href="/wiki/Dodge" title="Dodge">Dodge</a> being his first big auto client. At the Paris Motor Show in October 1924, Citroën introduced the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Type_B10" title="Citroën Type B10">Citroën B10</a>, the first all-steel body in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-citroen.co.uk_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-citroen.co.uk-12">[12]</a></sup> The cars were initially successful in the marketplace, but soon competitors (who were still using a <a href="/wiki/Wood" title="Wood">wooden</a> structure for their bodies) introduced new body designs. Citroën did not redesign the bodies of his cars. Citroëns still sold in large quantities in spite of not changing the body design, but the car's low price was the main selling point and Citroën experienced heavy losses.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2007)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:787px;max-width:787px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Paris_-_Bonhams_2013_-_Citro%C3%ABn_P19B_chenillette_K%C3%A9gresse_-_1931_-_004.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Paris_-_Bonhams_2013_-_Citro%C3%ABn_P19B_chenillette_K%C3%A9gresse_-_1931_-_004.jpg/200px-Paris_-_Bonhams_2013_-_Citro%C3%ABn_P19B_chenillette_K%C3%A9gresse_-_1931_-_004.jpg" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Paris_-_Bonhams_2013_-_Citro%C3%ABn_P19B_chenillette_K%C3%A9gresse_-_1931_-_004.jpg/300px-Paris_-_Bonhams_2013_-_Citro%C3%ABn_P19B_chenillette_K%C3%A9gresse_-_1931_-_004.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Paris_-_Bonhams_2013_-_Citro%C3%ABn_P19B_chenillette_K%C3%A9gresse_-_1931_-_004.jpg/400px-Paris_-_Bonhams_2013_-_Citro%C3%ABn_P19B_chenillette_K%C3%A9gresse_-_1931_-_004.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4752" data-file-height="3168" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">1931 C4 based Citroën P19B <a href="/wiki/K%C3%A9gresse_track" title="Kégresse track">Kégresse track</a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:230px;max-width:230px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Citroen_Rosalie_Coupe_15CV_Anet.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Citroen_Rosalie_Coupe_15CV_Anet.jpg/228px-Citroen_Rosalie_Coupe_15CV_Anet.jpg" width="228" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Citroen_Rosalie_Coupe_15CV_Anet.jpg/342px-Citroen_Rosalie_Coupe_15CV_Anet.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Citroen_Rosalie_Coupe_15CV_Anet.jpg/456px-Citroen_Rosalie_Coupe_15CV_Anet.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1507" data-file-height="878" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">1933 <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Rosalie" title="Citroën Rosalie">Citroën Rosalie Coupe 15CV</a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:168px;max-width:168px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Citroen_8CV_front.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Citroen_8CV_front.JPG/166px-Citroen_8CV_front.JPG" width="166" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Citroen_8CV_front.JPG/249px-Citroen_8CV_front.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Citroen_8CV_front.JPG/332px-Citroen_8CV_front.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2500" data-file-height="2000" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Citroën 8CV</div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:179px;max-width:179px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:1933_Citro%C3%ABn_P17_C_K%C3%A9gresse_(rs).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/1933_Citro%C3%ABn_P17_C_K%C3%A9gresse_%28rs%29.jpg/177px-1933_Citro%C3%ABn_P17_C_K%C3%A9gresse_%28rs%29.jpg" width="177" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/1933_Citro%C3%ABn_P17_C_K%C3%A9gresse_%28rs%29.jpg/266px-1933_Citro%C3%ABn_P17_C_K%C3%A9gresse_%28rs%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/1933_Citro%C3%ABn_P17_C_K%C3%A9gresse_%28rs%29.jpg/354px-1933_Citro%C3%ABn_P17_C_K%C3%A9gresse_%28rs%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4896" data-file-height="3672" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">1933 C4 based Citroën P17 C <a href="/wiki/K%C3%A9gresse_track" title="Kégresse track">Kégresse track</a></div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<p>In 1927, the bank <a href="/wiki/Lazard" title="Lazard">Lazard</a> helped Citroën by bringing new, much-needed funds as well as by renegotiating its debt—for example, by buying out the SOVAC. It went even further by entering in its capital and being represented at the board. The three directors sent by <a href="/wiki/Lazard" title="Lazard">Lazard</a> were <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raymond_Philippe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raymond Philippe (page does not exist)">Raymond Philippe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andre_Meyer" class="mw-redirect" title="Andre Meyer">Andre Meyer</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Paul_Frantzen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Paul Frantzen (page does not exist)">Paul Frantzen</a>.</p>
<p>André Citroën perceived the need to differentiate his product, to avoid the low price competition surrounding his conventional rear drive models in the late 1920s/early 1930s. In 1933, Citroën introduced the Rosalie, the first commercially available passenger car with a <a href="/wiki/Diesel_engine" title="Diesel engine">diesel engine</a>, developed with <a href="/wiki/Harry_Ricardo" title="Harry Ricardo">Harry Ricardo</a>.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Traction_Avant_and_Michelin_ownership">Traction Avant and Michelin ownership</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Traction Avant and Michelin ownership">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Traction_Avant">Traction Avant</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Traction Avant">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant" title="Citroën Traction Avant">Traction Avant</a> is a car that pioneered mass production of three revolutionary features that are still in use today: <a href="/wiki/Unibody" class="mw-redirect" title="Unibody">a unitary body with no separate frame</a>, four-wheel <a href="/wiki/Independent_suspension" title="Independent suspension">independent suspension</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Front-wheel_drive" title="Front-wheel drive">front-wheel drive</a>. The vast majority of cars for many decades were similar in conception to the <a href="/wiki/Ford_Model_T" title="Ford Model T">Ford Model T</a> – a body bolted onto a <a href="/wiki/Vehicle_frame" title="Vehicle frame">ladder frame</a> which held all the mechanical elements of the car, a <a href="/wiki/Suspension_(vehicle)#Suspension_geometry" title="Suspension (vehicle)">solid rear axle</a> that rigidly connected the rear wheels, and <a href="/wiki/Rear_wheel_drive" class="mw-redirect" title="Rear wheel drive">rear wheel drive</a>. The <i>Model T school</i> of automobile engineering proved popular, because it was thought to be cheap to build, but it did pose dynamic defects as cars became more capable, and resulted in a heavier car, which is why cars today are more like the Traction Avant than the Model T under the skin.</p>
<p>Citroën commissioned the American <a href="/wiki/Budd_Company" title="Budd Company">Budd Company</a> to create a prototype, which evolved into the 7-horsepower (<a href="/wiki/Horsepower#CV_and_cv" title="Horsepower">CV</a>), 32&#160;hp (24&#160;kW) Traction Avant of 1934.</p>
<div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:836px;max-width:836px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:157px;max-width:157px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant_convertible.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant_convertible.JPG/155px-Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant_convertible.JPG" width="155" height="116" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant_convertible.JPG/233px-Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant_convertible.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant_convertible.JPG/310px-Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant_convertible.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="2736" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Pre-war <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant" title="Citroën Traction Avant">Citroën Traction Avant</a> Cabriolet</div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:262px;max-width:262px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Citroen_B11_Sport_4-Door_Berline_1951.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Citroen_B11_Sport_4-Door_Berline_1951.jpg/260px-Citroen_B11_Sport_4-Door_Berline_1951.jpg" width="260" height="112" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Citroen_B11_Sport_4-Door_Berline_1951.jpg/390px-Citroen_B11_Sport_4-Door_Berline_1951.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Citroen_B11_Sport_4-Door_Berline_1951.jpg/520px-Citroen_B11_Sport_4-Door_Berline_1951.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="346" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant" title="Citroën Traction Avant">Citroën Traction Avant</a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:227px;max-width:227px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant_L%C3%A9g%C3%A8re_rear.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant_L%C3%A9g%C3%A8re_rear.JPG/225px-Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant_L%C3%A9g%C3%A8re_rear.JPG" width="225" height="114" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant_L%C3%A9g%C3%A8re_rear.JPG/338px-Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant_L%C3%A9g%C3%A8re_rear.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant_L%C3%A9g%C3%A8re_rear.JPG/450px-Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant_L%C3%A9g%C3%A8re_rear.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2412" data-file-height="1221" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant" title="Citroën Traction Avant">Citroën Traction Avant</a> Légère rear view</div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:182px;max-width:182px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:1956_Citroen_Traction_Avant_-_blue_-_svr_(4637749504).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/1956_Citroen_Traction_Avant_-_blue_-_svr_%284637749504%29.jpg/180px-1956_Citroen_Traction_Avant_-_blue_-_svr_%284637749504%29.jpg" width="180" height="113" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/1956_Citroen_Traction_Avant_-_blue_-_svr_%284637749504%29.jpg/270px-1956_Citroen_Traction_Avant_-_blue_-_svr_%284637749504%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/1956_Citroen_Traction_Avant_-_blue_-_svr_%284637749504%29.jpg/360px-1956_Citroen_Traction_Avant_-_blue_-_svr_%284637749504%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1680" data-file-height="1050" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">1956 <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant" title="Citroën Traction Avant">Citroën Traction Avant</a></div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Achieving quick development of the Traction Avant, tearing down and rebuilding the factory (in five months), and the extensive marketing efforts were investments that were too costly for Citroën to do all at once, causing the financial ruin of the company. In December 1934, despite the assistance of the Michelin company, Citroën filed for bankruptcy. Within the month, <a href="/wiki/Michelin" title="Michelin">Michelin</a>, already the car manufacturer's largest creditor, became its principal shareholder.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> Fortunately for Michelin, the technologically advanced <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant" title="Citroën Traction Avant">Traction Avant</a> met with market acceptance, and the basic philosophy of cutting edge technology used as a differentiator continued until the late 1990s. <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Michelin" title="Pierre Michelin">Pierre Michelin</a> became the chairman of Citroën early in 1935. <a href="/wiki/Pierre-Jules_Boulanger" title="Pierre-Jules Boulanger">Pierre-Jules Boulanger</a>, his deputy became the vice-president of Citroën and chief of the engineering and design department.</p>
<p>In 1935, founder <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Citro%C3%ABn" title="André Citroën">André Citroën</a> died from stomach cancer.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Research_breakthroughs">Research breakthroughs</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Research breakthroughs">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p><a href="/wiki/Pierre-Jules_Boulanger" title="Pierre-Jules Boulanger">Pierre-Jules Boulanger</a> had been a First World War air reconnaissance photography specialist with the <a href="/wiki/French_Air_Force" title="French Air Force">French Air Force</a>. He was capable and effective and finished the war having risen to the rank of captain. He was also courageous, having been decorated with the Military Cross and the Legion of Honour. He started working for <a href="/wiki/Michelin" title="Michelin">Michelin</a> in 1918, reporting directly to <a href="/wiki/%C3%89douard_Michelin_(born_1859)" class="mw-redirect" title="Édouard Michelin (born 1859)">Édouard Michelin</a>, co-director and founder of the business. Boulanger joined the Michelin board in 1922. He became president of Citroën in January 1938 after the death in a road accident his friend <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Michelin" title="Pierre Michelin">Pierre Michelin</a><sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1938_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1938-14">[14]</a></sup> and kept his position until his own death in 1950. In 1938, he also became Michelin's joint managing director.</p>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/German_occupation_of_France_in_World_War_II" class="mw-redirect" title="German occupation of France in World War II">German occupation of France in World War II</a> Boulanger refused to meet Dr. <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Porsche" title="Ferdinand Porsche">Ferdinand Porsche</a> or communicate with the German authorities except through intermediaries. He organized a "go slow" on production of trucks for the <a href="/wiki/Wehrmacht" title="Wehrmacht">Wehrmacht</a>, many of which were sabotaged at the factory, by putting the notch on the oil dipstick in the wrong place, resulting in engine seizure. In 1944 when the <a href="/wiki/Gestapo" title="Gestapo">Gestapo</a> headquarters in Paris was sacked by the <a href="/wiki/French_Resistance" title="French Resistance">French Resistance</a>, his name was prominent on a <a href="/wiki/Nazi" class="mw-redirect" title="Nazi">Nazi</a> blacklist of the most important "enemies of the Reich" to be arrested in the event of an allied invasion of France.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup></p>
<p>Citroën researchers, including <a href="/wiki/Paul_Mag%C3%A8s" title="Paul Magès">Paul Magès</a>, continued their work in secret, against the express orders of the Germans, and developed the concepts that were later brought to market in three remarkable vehicles – a small car (2CV), a delivery van (Type H), and a large, swift family car (DS). These were widely regarded by contemporary <a href="/wiki/Journalists" class="mw-redirect" title="Journalists">journalists</a> as <a href="/wiki/Avant_garde" class="mw-redirect" title="Avant garde">avant garde</a>, even radical, solutions to automotive design.</p>
<p>This began a decades long period of unusual <a href="/wiki/Brand_loyalty" title="Brand loyalty">brand loyalty</a> normally seen in the automobile industry only in niche brands, like <a href="/wiki/Porsche" title="Porsche">Porsche</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ferrari" title="Ferrari">Ferrari</a>.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Deux_Chevaux">The Deux Chevaux</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: The Deux Chevaux">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Citroën unveiled the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_2CV" title="Citroën 2CV">2CV</a>—signifying two <a href="/wiki/Tax_horsepower" title="Tax horsepower">fiscal horsepower</a>, initially only 12&#160;hp (8.9&#160;kW)—at the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Salon" class="mw-redirect" title="Paris Salon">Paris Salon</a> in 1948. The car became a bestseller, achieving the designer's aim of providing rural <a href="/wiki/French_people" title="French people">French people</a> with a motorized alternative to the <a href="/wiki/Horse" title="Horse">horse</a>. It was unusually inexpensive to purchase and with its tiny two cylinder engine, inexpensive to run as well. The 2CV pioneered a very soft, interconnected suspension, but did not have the more complex <a href="/wiki/Self-levelling_suspension" title="Self-levelling suspension">self-levelling feature</a>. This car remained in production, with only minor changes, until 1990 and was a common sight on French roads until recently. 8.8 Million 2CV variants were produced in the period 1948–1990.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:841px;max-width:841px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">

</div>

</div>

<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_H_Van" title="Citroën H Van">Citroën H Van</a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Amboise_11.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Amboise_11.JPG/200px-Amboise_11.JPG" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Amboise_11.JPG/300px-Amboise_11.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Amboise_11.JPG/400px-Amboise_11.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1809" data-file-height="1357" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Ami" title="Citroën Ami">Citroën Ami</a></div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
</div>
</div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Goddess">The Goddess</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: The Goddess">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>1955 saw the introduction of the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS" title="Citroën DS">DS</a>, the first full usage of Citroën's now legendary <a href="/wiki/Hydropneumatic" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydropneumatic">hydropneumatic</a> <a href="/wiki/Self-levelling_suspension" title="Self-levelling suspension">self-levelling suspension</a> system, tested on the rear suspension of the Traction in 1954.</p>
<p>The DS was the first production car with modern <a href="/wiki/Disc_brakes" class="mw-redirect" title="Disc brakes">disc brakes</a>.</p>
<p>A single high-pressure <a href="/wiki/Hydraulic" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydraulic">hydraulic</a> system was used to activate the <a href="/wiki/Power_steering" title="Power steering">power steering</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suspension_(vehicle)" title="Suspension (vehicle)">suspension</a>, and brakes. Brakes were power assisted, to multiply force applied by the driver.</p>
<p>On the Citromatic (semi-<a href="/wiki/Automatic_transmission" title="Automatic transmission">automatic transmission</a>) version, the system also operated the <a href="/wiki/Clutch" title="Clutch">clutch</a>, through a system of pistons in the <a href="/wiki/Gearbox" class="mw-redirect" title="Gearbox">gearbox</a> cover to shift the gears in the <a href="/wiki/Transmission_(mechanics)" title="Transmission (mechanics)">transmission</a>.</p>
<p>From 1968, the DS also introduced <a href="/wiki/Headlamp#Directional_headlamps" title="Headlamp">directional headlights, that moved with the steering</a>, improving visibility at night.</p>
<p>The streamlined car was remarkable for its era, and had a remarkable-sounding name – in French, <i>DS</i> is pronounced <span title="English pronunciation respelling"><a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i><b><span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">DAY</span></span></b>-ess</i></a></span>, the same as <span lang="fr"><i>déesse</i></span>, which means <i><a href="/wiki/Goddess" title="Goddess">Goddess</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> The DS placed third in the 1999 <a href="/wiki/Car_of_the_Century" title="Car of the Century">Car of the Century</a> competition.</p>
<div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:871px;max-width:871px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:229px;max-width:229px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Citroen_ID19_or_DS_19_mfd_1962_registered_for_UK_roads_Feb_1990_1911cc.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Citroen_ID19_or_DS_19_mfd_1962_registered_for_UK_roads_Feb_1990_1911cc.jpg/227px-Citroen_ID19_or_DS_19_mfd_1962_registered_for_UK_roads_Feb_1990_1911cc.jpg" width="227" height="151" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Citroen_ID19_or_DS_19_mfd_1962_registered_for_UK_roads_Feb_1990_1911cc.jpg/341px-Citroen_ID19_or_DS_19_mfd_1962_registered_for_UK_roads_Feb_1990_1911cc.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Citroen_ID19_or_DS_19_mfd_1962_registered_for_UK_roads_Feb_1990_1911cc.jpg/454px-Citroen_ID19_or_DS_19_mfd_1962_registered_for_UK_roads_Feb_1990_1911cc.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3450" data-file-height="2300" /></a></div>

</div>

<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:203px;max-width:203px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:2_DS_Citro%C3%ABn.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/2_DS_Citro%C3%ABn.jpg/201px-2_DS_Citro%C3%ABn.jpg" width="201" height="151" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/2_DS_Citro%C3%ABn.jpg/302px-2_DS_Citro%C3%ABn.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/2_DS_Citro%C3%ABn.jpg/402px-2_DS_Citro%C3%ABn.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4896" data-file-height="3672" /></a></div>

</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:229px;max-width:229px">

<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">1974 <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS" title="Citroën DS">Citroën DS</a></div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
</div>
</div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="High_pressure_hydraulics">High pressure hydraulics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: High pressure hydraulics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>This high-pressure hydraulic system would form the basis of over 9 million Citroën cars, including the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS" title="Citroën DS">DS</a>, <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_SM" title="Citroën SM">SM</a>, <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_GS" title="Citroën GS">GS</a>, <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_CX" title="Citroën CX">CX</a>, <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_BX" title="Citroën BX">BX</a>, <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_XM" title="Citroën XM">XM</a>, <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Xantia" title="Citroën Xantia">Xantia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C5" title="Citroën C5">C5</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C6" title="Citroën C6">C6</a>. <a href="/wiki/Self-levelling_suspension" title="Self-levelling suspension">Self-levelling suspension</a> is the principal user benefit – the car maintains a constant ride height above the road regardless of passenger and cargo load, despite the very soft suspension. <a href="/wiki/Hydropneumatic_suspension" title="Hydropneumatic suspension">This type of suspension</a> is uniquely able to <a href="/wiki/Ride_quality" title="Ride quality">absorb road irregularities</a> without disturbing the occupants.<sup id="cite_ref-autotraderclassics.com_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autotraderclassics.com-18">[18]</a></sup> It is often compared to riding on a <i><a href="/wiki/Magic_carpet" title="Magic carpet">magic carpet</a></i> for this reason.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup></p>
<p>These vehicles shared the distinguishing feature of rising to operating <a href="/wiki/Ride_height" title="Ride height">ride height</a> when the engine was turned on, like a "mechanical camel" (per <i>Car &amp; Driver</i> magazine). A lever beside the driver's seat allowed the driver to adjust the height of the car, later replaced with an electronic switch. The height adjustability of the suspension allows for clearing obstacles, fording shallow (slow-moving) streams, and changing tires.</p>
<p>Citroën was undercapitalised, so its vehicles had a tendency to be underdeveloped at launch, with limited distribution and service networks outside France. As a result, early DS models experienced teething issues with the novel suspension.<sup id="cite_ref-autotraderclassics.com_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autotraderclassics.com-18">[18]</a></sup> The hydropneumatics were sorted out and became reliable.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup></p>
<p>Licensing such a technological leap forward was pursued to a limited extent – in 1965, the <a href="/wiki/Rolls-Royce_Silver_Shadow" title="Rolls-Royce Silver Shadow">Rolls-Royce Silver Shadow</a> included this suspension. The 1963 <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_600" title="Mercedes-Benz 600">Mercedes-Benz 600</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_300SEL_6.3" title="Mercedes-Benz 300SEL 6.3">Mercedes-Benz 300SEL 6.3</a> tried to replicate the advantages with a costly, complex, and expensive to maintain <a href="/wiki/Air_suspension" title="Air suspension">air suspension</a> that avoided the Citroën patented technology.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> By 1975, the <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_450SEL_6.9" title="Mercedes-Benz 450SEL 6.9">Mercedes-Benz 450SEL 6.9</a> could finally be produced with the proven <a href="/wiki/Hydropneumatic_suspension" title="Hydropneumatic suspension">hydropneumatic suspension</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz" title="Mercedes-Benz">Mercedes-Benz</a> continues to offer variations on this technology today.</p>
<p>During Citroën's 1968–1975 venture with <a href="/wiki/Maserati" title="Maserati">Maserati</a>, the Citroën high-pressure hydraulic system was used on several Maserati models, for power clutch operation (Bora), power pedal adjustment (Bora), pop-up headlights (Bora, Merak), brakes (Bora, Merak, Khamsin), steering (Khamsin), and the entire <a href="/wiki/Maserati_Quattroporte" title="Maserati Quattroporte">Quattroporte II</a> prototype, which was a four-door <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_SM" title="Citroën SM">Citroën SM</a> under the skin.<sup id="cite_ref-citroencarclub.com_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-citroencarclub.com-22">[22]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Aerodynamic_pioneer">Aerodynamic pioneer</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Aerodynamic pioneer">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Citroën was one of the early pioneers of the now widespread trend of <a href="/wiki/Aerodynamic" class="mw-redirect" title="Aerodynamic">aerodynamic</a> automobile design, which helps to reduce <a href="/wiki/Fuel_consumption" class="mw-redirect" title="Fuel consumption">fuel consumption</a> and improve high-speed performance by reducing <a href="/wiki/Drag_coefficient" title="Drag coefficient">wind resistance</a>. The cruising speed was the same as the top speed because of these efforts – the DS could happily run at 100&#160;mph without disturbing the occupants.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> The firm began using a <a href="/wiki/Wind_tunnel" title="Wind tunnel">wind tunnel</a> in the 1950s, enabling them to create highly streamlined cars such as the DS that were years ahead of their time. So good were the aerodynamics of the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_CX" title="Citroën CX">CX</a> that it took its name from the term used to measure drag coeffient: <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" >
<semantics>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
<msub>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi mathvariant="bold">c</mi>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi>
</mrow>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mspace width="thinmathspace" />
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle {\mathbf {c}}_{\mathrm {x} }\,}</annotation>
</semantics>
</math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4012b1b2c325592ffcc549d915dd4157d062fbe2" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.671ex; width:2.693ex; height:2.009ex;" alt="{\mathbf c}_{{\mathrm x}}\," /></span>.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Expansion_and_financial_challenges">Expansion and financial challenges</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Expansion and financial challenges">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>In the 1960s, Citroën undertook a series of financial and development maneuvers, aiming to build on its strength in the 1950s with the successful, 2CV, Type H, and DS models. Since Citroën went bankrupt in 1974, the effectiveness of these maneuvers is not clear.</p>
<p>The maneuvers were to address two key gaps facing the company.</p>
<p>The first was the lack of a midsize car between its own range of very small, cheap cars (<a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_2CV" title="Citroën 2CV">2CV</a>/<a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Ami" title="Citroën Ami">Ami</a>) and large, expensive cars (<a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS" title="Citroën DS">DS</a>/ID).<sup id="cite_ref-citroencarclub.com_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-citroencarclub.com-22">[22]</a></sup> In today's terms, this would be similar to a brand consisting only of the <a href="/wiki/Tata_Nano" title="Tata Nano">Tata Nano</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_E-Class" title="Mercedes-Benz E-Class">Mercedes-Benz E-Class</a>. Because of the potential volume, the midsize segment was the most profitable part of the car market, and in 1965 the <i>Citroënesque</i> <a href="/wiki/Renault_16" title="Renault 16">Renault 16</a> stepped in to address it.</p>
<p>The second large issue was the lack of a powerful engine suitable for export markets. The post-WW2 <a href="/wiki/Tax_horsepower" title="Tax horsepower">Tax horsepower</a> system in France was <a href="/wiki/Progressive_tax" title="Progressive tax">steeply progressive</a>, and vehicles over 2.0 (later 2.8) liters of engine displacement faced a heavy, annual tax. The result was that cars made in France were considered underpowered outside France.<sup id="cite_ref-Citro.C3.ABn_SM_1981_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Citro.C3.ABn_SM_1981-24">[24]</a></sup></p>
<p>For both the 1955 DS and 1974 CX models, development of the original engine around which the design was planned proved too expensive for the finances available, and the actual engine used in both cases was a modest and outdated four-cylinder design.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 1963, Citroën negotiated with <a href="/wiki/Peugeot" title="Peugeot">Peugeot</a> to cooperate in the purchase of raw materials and equipment. Talks were broken off in 1965.</p>
<p>In 1964, Citroën partnered with <a href="/wiki/NSU_Motorenwerke" title="NSU Motorenwerke">NSU Motorenwerke</a> to develop the <a href="/wiki/Wankel_engine" title="Wankel engine">Wankel engine</a> via the Comobil (later <a href="/wiki/Comotor" title="Comotor">Comotor</a>) subsidiary. For Citroën, this represented the chance for a technological end run around the French <a href="/wiki/Tax_horsepower" title="Tax horsepower">Tax horsepower</a> system – producing a more powerful car while maintaining a small engine. The first production car developed 106&#160;hp with a 1-liter engine,<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> while the standard GS delivered 55&#160;hp with a 1-liter engine.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 1965, Citroën took over the French carmaker <a href="/wiki/Panhard" title="Panhard">Panhard</a> in the hope of using Panhard's expertise in midsize cars. Cooperation between the two companies had begun 12&#160;years earlier, and they had agreed to a partial merger of their sales networks in 1953. Panhard ceased making vehicles in 1967.<sup id="cite_ref-citroencarclub.com_22-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-citroencarclub.com-22">[22]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 1967, Citroën purchased the truck manufacturer <a href="/wiki/Berliet" title="Berliet">Berliet</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-citroencarclub.com_22-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-citroencarclub.com-22">[22]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 1968, Citroën purchased the <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italian</a> <a href="/wiki/Sports_car" title="Sports car">sports car</a> <a href="/wiki/Automaker" class="mw-redirect" title="Automaker">maker</a> <a href="/wiki/Maserati" title="Maserati">Maserati</a>, again with an eye to producing a more powerful car while maintaining a small engine in line with the French <a href="/wiki/Tax_horsepower" title="Tax horsepower">tax horsepower</a> system.<sup id="cite_ref-Citro.C3.ABn_SM_1981_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Citro.C3.ABn_SM_1981-24">[24]</a></sup> The first production car developed 170&#160;hp with a 2.7-liter engine.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup></p>
<p>This was the 1970 <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_SM" title="Citroën SM">SM</a>, which featured a V6 Maserati engine, <a href="/wiki/Hydropneumatic_suspension" title="Hydropneumatic suspension">hydropneumatic suspension</a>, and a fully powered, self-centering steering system called <a href="/wiki/DIRAVI" title="DIRAVI">DIRAVI</a>. The SM was engineered as if it were replacing the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS" title="Citroën DS">DS</a> family car, a level of investment the small luxury <a href="/wiki/Grand_tourer" title="Grand tourer">Grand Touring car</a> sector alone would never be able to support, even in the best of circumstances.</p>
<p>The year 1968 also saw a restructuring of Citroën's worldwide operations under a new holding company, Citroën SA. <a href="/wiki/Michelin" title="Michelin">Michelin</a>, Citroën's longtime controlling shareholder, sold a 49% stake to <a href="/wiki/Fiat" class="mw-redirect" title="Fiat">Fiat</a> in what was referred to as the <i>PARDEVI</i> agreement (Participation et Développement Industriels).<sup id="cite_ref-citroencarclub.com_22-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-citroencarclub.com-22">[22]</a></sup></p>
<p>From a model range perspective, the 1970s started well for Citroën, supported by the successful launch of the long-awaited midsize <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_GS" title="Citroën GS">Citroën GS</a>, finally filling the huge gap between the 2CV and the DS – with a 1-liter, <a href="/wiki/Hydropneumatic_suspension" title="Hydropneumatic suspension">hydropneumatically suspended</a> car. The GS went on to sell 2.5 million units. 601,918 cars were produced just in 1972, up from 526,443 in 1971, and enough to lift the company past <a href="/wiki/Peugeot" title="Peugeot">Peugeot</a> into second place among French auto-makers when ranked by volume of units.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1972_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1972-29">[29]</a></sup></p>
<p>Circumstances became more unfavorable for Citroën as the 1970s progressed.</p>
<p>In 1973, <a href="/wiki/Fiat" class="mw-redirect" title="Fiat">Fiat</a> sold its 49% stake in the <i>PARDEVI</i> holding company (that owned Citroën) back to <a href="/wiki/Michelin" title="Michelin">Michelin</a>. The Citroën and Fiat joint announcement indicated that benefits foreseen for their union in 1968 had failed to materialise.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1974_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1974-30">[30]</a></sup> This was not in line with the tire company's long term strategy of ending involvements in the car manufacturing business, creating a very unstable ownership situation.<sup id="cite_ref-citroenet.org.uk_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-citroenet.org.uk-31">[31]</a></sup></p>
<p>Citroën suffered a financial blow with the <a href="/wiki/1973_energy_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="1973 energy crisis">1973 energy crisis</a>. While some models sold well (peak production of the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_2CV" title="Citroën 2CV">2CV and its derivatives</a> was 1974), the bets on <a href="/wiki/Comotor" title="Comotor">Comotor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maserati" title="Maserati">Maserati</a> both had what was now clearly a flaw – high fuel consumption engines.</p>
<p>The teams of Charles Marchetti and Citroën began working together on the development of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn_RE-2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Citroën RE-2 (page does not exist)">RE-2</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;(<a href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_RE-2" class="extiw" title="fr:Citroën RE-2">fr</a>)</span> <a href="/wiki/Helicopter" title="Helicopter">helicopter</a>.</p>
<p>In 1974, the carmaker withdrew from North America due to U.S. design regulations that outlawed core features of Citroën cars (see <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_SM" title="Citroën SM">Citroën SM</a>).</p>
<p>Huge losses at Citroën were caused by failure of the <a href="/wiki/Comotor" title="Comotor">Comotor</a> rotary engine venture, plus the <a href="/wiki/Strategic_management" title="Strategic management">strategic error</a> of going the <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7008473364000000000♠</span>15&#160;years</span> from 1955 to 1970 without a model in the profitable middle range of the European market, and the massive development costs for the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_GS" title="Citroën GS">GS</a>, <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_GS_Birotor" class="mw-redirect" title="Citroën GS Birotor">GS Birotor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_CX" title="Citroën CX">CX</a>, <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_SM" title="Citroën SM">SM</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maserati_Bora" title="Maserati Bora">Maserati Bora</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maserati_Merak" title="Maserati Merak">Maserati Merak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maserati_Quattroporte_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Maserati Quattroporte II">Maserati Quattroporte II</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Maserati_Khamsin" title="Maserati Khamsin">Maserati Khamsin</a> models— each a technological marvel in its own right.</p>
<p>40 years after the bankruptcy related to the <a href="/wiki/Traction_Avant" class="mw-redirect" title="Traction Avant">Traction Avant</a>, Citroën went bankrupt again, losing its existence as an independent entity, selling Berliet and Maserati, and closing Comotor.<sup id="cite_ref-citroencarclub.com_22-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-citroencarclub.com-22">[22]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:859px;max-width:859px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:247px;max-width:247px">

</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:162px;max-width:162px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:1982_Citroen_CX_Prestige.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/1982_Citroen_CX_Prestige.jpg/160px-1982_Citroen_CX_Prestige.jpg" width="160" height="167" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/1982_Citroen_CX_Prestige.jpg/240px-1982_Citroen_CX_Prestige.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/1982_Citroen_CX_Prestige.jpg/320px-1982_Citroen_CX_Prestige.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1617" data-file-height="1689" /></a></div>

</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
</div>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="PSA_Peugeot_Citro.C3.ABn_era">PSA Peugeot Citroën era</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: PSA Peugeot Citroën era">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The French government feared large job losses, due to the poor cash flow situation at Citroën and the unstable ownership structure. It arranged talks between <a href="/wiki/Michelin" title="Michelin">Michelin</a> and Citroën and decided to merge Automobiles Citroën and Automobiles Peugeot into a single company. A year after the break with Fiat, on 24 June 1974, Citroën announced their new partnership, this time with Peugeot.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1974_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1974-30">[30]</a></sup> Michelin agreed to transfer control of the business to Peugeot.<sup id="cite_ref-citroencarclub.com_22-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-citroencarclub.com-22">[22]</a></sup></p>
<p>In December 1974 Peugeot S.A. acquired a 38.2% share of Citroën. On 9 April 1976<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> they increased their stake of the then bankrupt company to 89.95%, thus creating the <i>PSA Group</i> (where PSA is short for Peugeot <a href="/wiki/Soci%C3%A9t%C3%A9_Anonyme" class="mw-redirect" title="Société Anonyme">Société Anonyme</a>), becoming <a href="/wiki/PSA_Peugeot_Citro%C3%ABn" class="mw-redirect" title="PSA Peugeot Citroën">PSA Peugeot Citroën</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup></p>
<p>Citroën sold off <a href="/wiki/Maserati" title="Maserati">Maserati</a> to <a href="/wiki/De_Tomaso" title="De Tomaso">De Tomaso</a> in May 1975, and the Italian firm was able to exploit the sales potential of the models and technology developed by Citroën, as well as exploit the image of the Maserati <a href="/wiki/Aspirational_brand" title="Aspirational brand">brand</a> in a downward <a href="/wiki/Brand_extension" title="Brand extension">brand extension</a> to sell 40,000 of the newly designed <a href="/wiki/Maserati_Biturbo" title="Maserati Biturbo">Bi-Turbo</a> models. <a href="/wiki/Berliet" title="Berliet">Berliet</a> was sold to <a href="/wiki/Renault" title="Renault">Renault</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-citroencarclub.com_22-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-citroencarclub.com-22">[22]</a></sup></p>
<p>The PSA venture was a financial success from 1976 to 1979. Citroën had two successful new designs in the market at this time (the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_GS" title="Citroën GS">GS</a> and <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_CX" title="Citroën CX">CX</a>), a resurgent <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_2CV" title="Citroën 2CV">Citroën 2CV</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Dyane" title="Citroën Dyane">Citroën Dyane</a> in the wake of the oil crisis, and <a href="/wiki/Peugeot" title="Peugeot">Peugeot</a> was typically prudent in its own finances, launching the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_104" title="Peugeot 104">Peugeot 104</a> based <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Visa" title="Citroën Visa">Citroën Visa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_LNA" title="Citroën LNA">Citroën LNA</a>.</p>
<p>PSA then purchased the ageing assets and substantial liabilities of <a href="/wiki/Chrysler_Europe" title="Chrysler Europe">Chrysler Europe</a> for $1, leading to losses from 1980 to 1985. Since PSA needed a new brand for the Chrysler cars, it resurrected the <a href="/wiki/Talbot" title="Talbot">Talbot</a> name.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Trade_union_problems">Trade union problems</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Trade union problems">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>In the early 1980s, Citroën was targeted by union action.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1982_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1982-34">[34]</a></sup> Events led to a mass demonstration in the streets of Paris on 25 May 1982.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1982_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1982-34">[34]</a></sup> Approximately 27,000 Citroën workers demonstrated in affirmation of their wish to work at a company which was being picketed by striking workers who had been blocking access to the factories for four weeks.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1982_34-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1982-34">[34]</a></sup> The demonstrations were successful and six days later work at the plants resumed. Jacques Lombard, one of the company’s senior managers, had gone public with his concerns criticising the strikes.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1982_34-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1982-34">[34]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Taming_the_innovative_spirit">Taming the innovative spirit</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Taming the innovative spirit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>PSA gradually diluted Citroën's ambitious attitude to engineering and styling in an effort to <a href="/wiki/Rebranding" title="Rebranding">rebrand</a> the marque to appeal to a wider market. In the 1980s, Citroën models became increasingly Peugeot-based, following the worldwide motor industry trend called "platform sharing." The 1982 <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_BX" title="Citroën BX">BX</a> used the <a href="/wiki/Hydropneumatic" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydropneumatic">hydropneumatic</a> suspension system and still had a <i>Citroën-esque</i> appearance, while being powered by Peugeot-derived engines and using the floorpan later seen on the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_405" title="Peugeot 405">Peugeot 405</a>. By the late 1980s, many of the distinctive features of the marque had been removed or diluted—conventional Peugeot's switchgear replaced Citroën's quirky but ergonomic "Lunule" designs,<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> complete with self-cancelling indicators that Citroën had refused to adopt on ergonomic grounds. While the cars were more banal,<sup id="cite_ref-citroenet.org.uk_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-citroenet.org.uk-31">[31]</a></sup> sales continued steadily.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Geographical_expansion">Geographical expansion</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Geographical expansion">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Citroën expanded into many new geographic markets. In the late 1970s, the firm developed a small car for production in <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a> known as the <a href="/wiki/Oltcit" title="Oltcit">Oltcit</a>, which it sold in <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Axel" title="Citroën Axel">Citroën Axel</a>. That joint venture has ended, but a new one between PSA and <a href="/wiki/Toyota" title="Toyota">Toyota</a> is now producing cars like the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C1" title="Citroën C1">Citroën C1</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">Czech Republic</a>.</p>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Dongfeng_Peugeot-Citro%C3%ABn_Automobile" class="mw-redirect" title="Dongfeng Peugeot-Citroën Automobile">China</a>, Citroën began selling cars in 1984 <sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> and building them in 1994 – today it is a major overseas market. <sup id="cite_ref-ForbesChina_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ForbesChina-37">[37]</a></sup> The current range of family cars that includes the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C3" title="Citroën C3">C3</a> and <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Xsara" title="Citroën Xsara">Xsara</a> and locally designed cars like the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Fukang" title="Citroën Fukang">Fukang</a> and <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Elys%C3%A9e" title="Citroën Elysée">Elysée</a> models. The Citroën brand recently increased its Chinese sales by 30% in an overall market growth of 11%<sup id="cite_ref-Automotive_News_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automotive_News-38">[38]</a></sup> and ranks highest in the 2014 customer satisfaction survey by JD Power in China.<sup id="cite_ref-JD_Power_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JD_Power-39">[39]</a></sup></p>
<p>Citroën is a global brand except in North America, where the company has not returned since the SM <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_SM#US_exports" title="Citroën SM">was effectively banned in 1974</a> for not meeting U.S. <a href="/wiki/National_Highway_Traffic_Safety_Administration" title="National Highway Traffic Safety Administration">National Highway Traffic Safety Administration</a> (NHTSA) bumper height regulations.</p>
<p>In 2016, Peugeot-Citroën South Africa (PCSA) announced that Citroën would be pulling out of <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a> after poor sales in the country. Citroën had returned to South Africa in 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> <sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">

</div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Recent_decades">Recent decades</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Recent decades">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>From 2003–2010, Citroën produced the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C3" title="Citroën C3">C3</a> Pluriel, an unusual convertible with allusions to the 1948–1990 2CV model, both in body style (such as the bonnet) and in its all-round practicality.</p>
<p>In 2001, Citroën acknowledged its history of innovation when it opened a museum of its many significant vehicles – the 'Conservatoire,' with 300 cars.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup></p>
<p>With the severe decline in European auto sales after 2009, worldwide sales of vehicles declined from 1,460,373 in 2010 to 1,435,688 in 2011, with 961,156 of these sold in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 2011, Groupe PSA was close to forming a partnership with BMW for the development of electric and hybrid vehicles between BMW and all of the PSA brands, but the talks fell through shortly after Groupe PSA, Citroën's parent company, announced a partnership with GM which later failed.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Dongfeng_Peugeot-Citro%C3%ABn" title="Dongfeng Peugeot-Citroën">Dongfeng Peugeot-Citroën</a> continues growing, and has developed 8 car designs exclusive to the China market. <sup id="cite_ref-ForbesChina_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ForbesChina-37">[37]</a></sup> Currently in China, Citroën (and <a href="/wiki/Peugeot" title="Peugeot">Peugeot</a>) face the same challenge as <a href="/wiki/Volkswagen" title="Volkswagen">Volkswagen</a>: too many <a href="/wiki/Sedan_(automobile)" title="Sedan (automobile)">sedans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hatchback" title="Hatchback">hatchbacks</a>, without enough models in the strong selling <a href="/wiki/SUV" class="mw-redirect" title="SUV">SUV</a> and <a href="/wiki/Minivan" title="Minivan">minivan</a>/MPV categories.<sup id="cite_ref-ForbesChina_37-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ForbesChina-37">[37]</a></sup></p>
<p>The brand ranks highest in the 2014 customer satisfaction survey by JD Power in China, above luxury brands like <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz" title="Mercedes-Benz">Mercedes-Benz</a> and <a href="/wiki/BMW" title="BMW">BMW</a>, and above mass market brands like Volkswagen ranking only thirteenth and seventeenth.<sup id="cite_ref-JD_Power_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JD_Power-39">[39]</a></sup> On the 10 first months of 2014 in China, the sales of Donfeng Citroën cars increased by 30% in an overall market growth of 11%.<sup id="cite_ref-Automotive_News_38-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automotive_News-38">[38]</a></sup></p>
<p>Despite the near death financial experience of <a href="/wiki/PSA_Peugeot_Citro%C3%ABn" class="mw-redirect" title="PSA Peugeot Citroën">PSA Peugeot Citroën</a> in 2014, and financial rescue by <a href="/wiki/Dongfeng_Motors" class="mw-redirect" title="Dongfeng Motors">Dongfeng Motors</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> the "Citroën" and "DS" brands are developing new technologies and are both planned to grow 15% by 2020, according to Citroën <a href="/wiki/CEO" class="mw-redirect" title="CEO">CEO</a> Linda Jackson and DS <a href="/wiki/CEO" class="mw-redirect" title="CEO">CEO</a> Yves Bonnefont.<sup id="cite_ref-AutocarUK_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AutocarUK-45">[45]</a></sup></p>
<p>Since 2013, the model <a href="/wiki/Carolina_%22Pampita%22_Ardoha%C3%ADn" title="Carolina &quot;Pampita&quot; Ardohaín">Carolina "Pampita" Ardohaín</a> represents Citroën and its life style in some fashion films.<sup id="cite_ref-Pampita_y_el_Nuevo_Citro.C3.ABn_C4_Lounge_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pampita_y_el_Nuevo_Citro.C3.ABn_C4_Lounge-46">[46]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Pampita_y_el_Citro.C3.ABn_C4_Aircross_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pampita_y_el_Citro.C3.ABn_C4_Aircross-47">[47]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
