</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
</div>
</div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="DS_brand">DS brand</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: DS brand">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/DS_Automobiles" title="DS Automobiles">DS Automobiles</a></div>
<p>Citroën announced in early 2009 the development of a premiumbrand <b>DS</b>, for <b>Different Spirit</b> or <b>Distinctive Series</b> (although the reference to the historical <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS" title="Citroën DS">Citroën DS</a> is evident), to run in parallel to its mainstream cars. The slogan of the DS car marque is "Spirit of avant-garde".<sup id="cite_ref-DS_brand_spirit_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DS_brand_spirit-48">[48]</a></sup></p>
<p>This new series of cars started with the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS3" class="mw-redirect" title="Citroën DS3">Citroën DS3</a> in early 2010, a small car based on the floor plan of the new C3. The <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS3" class="mw-redirect" title="Citroën DS3">Citroën DS3</a> is based on the concept of the produced <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C3" title="Citroën C3">Citroën C3 Pluriel</a> model and the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS_Inside" title="Citroën DS Inside">Citroën DS Inside</a> concept car. The <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS3" class="mw-redirect" title="Citroën DS3">Citroën DS3</a> is customisable with various roof colours that can contrast with the body panels. The <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS3" class="mw-redirect" title="Citroën DS3">Citroën DS3</a> was named 2010 <i>Car of the Year</i> by <i><a href="/wiki/Top_Gear_Magazine" class="mw-redirect" title="Top Gear Magazine">Top Gear Magazine</a></i>, awarded first supermini four times in a row by the JD Power Satisfaction Survey UK<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> and second most efficient supermini (Citroën DS3 1.6 e-HDi 115 Airdream&#160;: True MPG 63.0mpg) by <i>What car&#160;?</i> behind the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C3" title="Citroën C3">Citroën C3</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> In 2013, the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS3" class="mw-redirect" title="Citroën DS3">Citroën DS3</a> was again the most sold premium subcompact car with 40% of these market shares in Europe, validating the business model of this product development.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2014)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>The DS series is deeply connected to Citroën, as the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS4" class="mw-redirect" title="Citroën DS4">DS4</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> launched in 2010, is based on the 2008 <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Hypnos" title="Citroën Hypnos">Citroën Hypnos</a> concept car and the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS5" class="mw-redirect" title="Citroën DS5">DS5</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> following in 2011, is based on the 2005 <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C-SportLounge" class="mw-redirect" title="Citroën C-SportLounge">Citroën C-SportLounge</a> concept car.</p>
<p>Their rear badge is a new DS logo rather than the familiar Citroën double chevron, and all will have markedly different styling from their equivalent sister car.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> Citroën has produced several dramatic-looking concept sports cars of late with the fully working <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Survolt" title="Citroën Survolt">Citroën Survolt</a><sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> being badged as a DS. Indeed, the 2014 <a href="/w/index.php?title=DS_Divine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DS Divine (page does not exist)">DS Divine</a> concept car develops the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Survolt" title="Citroën Survolt">Citroën Survolt</a> prototype as the future sport coupé of the DS range.</p>
<p>In China, Citroën has "stand alone" DS sale rooms, including vehicle plants built for the production of these vehicles. <sup id="cite_ref-ForbesChina_37-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ForbesChina-37">[37]</a></sup> Since 2014, Citroën sells the Chinese built <a href="/wiki/DS_5LS" title="DS 5LS">DS 5LS</a> and <a href="/wiki/DS_6WR" class="mw-redirect" title="DS 6WR">DS 6WR</a> in China.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:773px;max-width:773px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:172px;max-width:172px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:2010_Citro%C3%ABn_DS3_(MY10)_1.6_VTI_DStyle_Plus_3-door_hatchback_(2016-01-05)_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/2010_Citro%C3%ABn_DS3_%28MY10%29_1.6_VTI_DStyle_Plus_3-door_hatchback_%282016-01-05%29_01.jpg/170px-2010_Citro%C3%ABn_DS3_%28MY10%29_1.6_VTI_DStyle_Plus_3-door_hatchback_%282016-01-05%29_01.jpg" width="170" height="105" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/2010_Citro%C3%ABn_DS3_%28MY10%29_1.6_VTI_DStyle_Plus_3-door_hatchback_%282016-01-05%29_01.jpg/255px-2010_Citro%C3%ABn_DS3_%28MY10%29_1.6_VTI_DStyle_Plus_3-door_hatchback_%282016-01-05%29_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/2010_Citro%C3%ABn_DS3_%28MY10%29_1.6_VTI_DStyle_Plus_3-door_hatchback_%282016-01-05%29_01.jpg/340px-2010_Citro%C3%ABn_DS3_%28MY10%29_1.6_VTI_DStyle_Plus_3-door_hatchback_%282016-01-05%29_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3278" data-file-height="2021" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS3" class="mw-redirect" title="Citroën DS3">Citroën DS3</a>, the most sold <i>premium</i> car of its category</div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:224px;max-width:224px">

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Awards">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Citroën was recognized in the 1999 <a href="/wiki/Car_of_the_Century" title="Car of the Century">Car of the Century</a> competition as producing the third most influential car of the 20th century, the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS" title="Citroën DS">Citroën DS</a>, which trailed only the <a href="/wiki/Ford_Model_T" title="Ford Model T">Ford Model T</a> and BMC <a href="/wiki/Mini" title="Mini">Mini</a>.</p>
<p>Citroën has produced three winners of the 50-year-old <a href="/wiki/European_Car_of_the_Year" title="European Car of the Year">European Car of the Year</a> award, and many rated second or third place.</p>
<div class="plainlist">
<ul>
<li>1971 – <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_GS" title="Citroën GS">Citroën GS</a></li>
<li>1975 – <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_CX" title="Citroën CX">Citroën CX</a></li>
<li>1990 – <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_XM" title="Citroën XM">Citroën XM</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<p>Citroën has produced one winner of the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> <a href="/wiki/Motor_Trend_Car_of_the_Year" title="Motor Trend Car of the Year">Motor Trend Car of the Year</a> award – the original <a href="/wiki/Car_of_the_Year" title="Car of the Year">Car of the Year</a> designation, which began in 1949. This was especially significant because this award used to be only given to cars designed and built in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup></p>
<div class="plainlist">
<ul>
<li>1972 – <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_SM" title="Citroën SM">Citroën SM</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:865px;max-width:865px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:205px;max-width:205px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Citro%C3%ABn_XM_EuroCitro_2014.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Citro%C3%ABn_XM_EuroCitro_2014.jpg/203px-Citro%C3%ABn_XM_EuroCitro_2014.jpg" width="203" height="136" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Citro%C3%ABn_XM_EuroCitro_2014.jpg/305px-Citro%C3%ABn_XM_EuroCitro_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Citro%C3%ABn_XM_EuroCitro_2014.jpg/406px-Citro%C3%ABn_XM_EuroCitro_2014.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4858" data-file-height="3256" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_XM" title="Citroën XM">Citroën XM</a> 1990 COTY in Europe</div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:183px;max-width:183px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Citroen_C5_2.0_2011_(14207428889).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Citroen_C5_2.0_2011_%2814207428889%29.jpg/181px-Citroen_C5_2.0_2011_%2814207428889%29.jpg" width="181" height="136" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Citroen_C5_2.0_2011_%2814207428889%29.jpg/272px-Citroen_C5_2.0_2011_%2814207428889%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Citroen_C5_2.0_2011_%2814207428889%29.jpg/362px-Citroen_C5_2.0_2011_%2814207428889%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2250" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C5" title="Citroën C5">Citroën C5</a> 2009 COTY in Ireland and Spain</div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:232px;max-width:232px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Citro%C3%ABn_C4-Picasso_Mk2-7_places_Front.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Citro%C3%ABn_C4-Picasso_Mk2-7_places_Front.JPG/230px-Citro%C3%ABn_C4-Picasso_Mk2-7_places_Front.JPG" width="230" height="136" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Citro%C3%ABn_C4-Picasso_Mk2-7_places_Front.JPG/345px-Citro%C3%ABn_C4-Picasso_Mk2-7_places_Front.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Citro%C3%ABn_C4-Picasso_Mk2-7_places_Front.JPG/460px-Citro%C3%ABn_C4-Picasso_Mk2-7_places_Front.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4565" data-file-height="2697" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C4_Picasso" title="Citroën C4 Picasso">Citroën C4 Picasso</a>, 2014 COTY in Ireland</div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:237px;max-width:237px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Citro%C3%ABn_C4_Cactus_BlueHDi_100_Shine_Edition_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht_(3),_2._November_2014,_M%C3%BCnster.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Citro%C3%ABn_C4_Cactus_BlueHDi_100_Shine_Edition_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht_%283%29%2C_2._November_2014%2C_M%C3%BCnster.jpg/235px-Citro%C3%ABn_C4_Cactus_BlueHDi_100_Shine_Edition_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht_%283%29%2C_2._November_2014%2C_M%C3%BCnster.jpg" width="235" height="137" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Citro%C3%ABn_C4_Cactus_BlueHDi_100_Shine_Edition_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht_%283%29%2C_2._November_2014%2C_M%C3%BCnster.jpg/353px-Citro%C3%ABn_C4_Cactus_BlueHDi_100_Shine_Edition_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht_%283%29%2C_2._November_2014%2C_M%C3%BCnster.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Citro%C3%ABn_C4_Cactus_BlueHDi_100_Shine_Edition_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht_%283%29%2C_2._November_2014%2C_M%C3%BCnster.jpg/470px-Citro%C3%ABn_C4_Cactus_BlueHDi_100_Shine_Edition_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht_%283%29%2C_2._November_2014%2C_M%C3%BCnster.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3430" data-file-height="2005" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C4_Cactus" title="Citroën C4 Cactus">Citroën C4 Cactus</a>, Car of the year in Spain, Denmark, and second at the Car of the year in Europe 2015</div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Citroën has produced eight <i>Auto Europa</i> winners in 28 years, since 1987. <i>Auto Europa</i> is the prize awarded by the jury of the Italian Union of Automotive Journalists (UIGA), which annually celebrates the best car produced at least at 10,000 units in the 27 countries of the European Union: <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_XM" title="Citroën XM">Citroën XM</a>(1990), <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_ZX" title="Citroën ZX">Citroën ZX</a> (1992), <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Xantia" title="Citroën Xantia">Citroën Xantia</a> (1994), <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Xsara_Picasso" title="Citroën Xsara Picasso">Citroën Xsara Picasso</a> (2001), <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C5" title="Citroën C5">Citroën C5</a> (2002), <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C3" title="Citroën C3">Citroën C3</a> (2003), <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C4" title="Citroën C4">Citroën C4</a> (2005) and <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS4" class="mw-redirect" title="Citroën DS4">Citroën DS4</a> (2012).</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Citro.C3.ABn_Racing">Citroën Racing</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Citroën Racing">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">See also: <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_World_Rally_Team" title="Citroën World Rally Team">Citroën World Rally Team</a> and <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_World_Touring_Car_Team" title="Citroën World Touring Car Team">Citroën World Touring Car Team</a></div>
<p><b>Citroën Racing</b>, previously known as <b>Citroën Sport</b> and before that as <b>Citroën Competitions</b>, is the team responsible for Citroën's sporting activities. It is a successful winning competitor in the <a href="/wiki/World_Rally_Championship" title="World Rally Championship">World Rally Championship</a> and in the <a href="/wiki/World_Touring_Car_Championship" title="World Touring Car Championship">World Touring Car Championship</a>.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_rally_wins_for_Citro.C3.ABn_vehicles">Early rally wins for Citroën vehicles</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Early rally wins for Citroën vehicles">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Timo_Korpivaara_-_1956_Rally_Finland.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Timo_Korpivaara_-_1956_Rally_Finland.jpg/250px-Timo_Korpivaara_-_1956_Rally_Finland.jpg" width="250" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Timo_Korpivaara_-_1956_Rally_Finland.jpg/375px-Timo_Korpivaara_-_1956_Rally_Finland.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Timo_Korpivaara_-_1956_Rally_Finland.jpg/500px-Timo_Korpivaara_-_1956_Rally_Finland.jpg 2x" data-file-width="567" data-file-height="340" /></a>

1956 <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS" title="Citroën DS">Citroën DS</a> at <a href="/wiki/Rally_Finland" title="Rally Finland">Rally Finland</a>/1000 Lakes Rally</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a href="/wiki/File:R%C3%A9tromobile_2011_-_Citro%C3%ABn_SM_Rallye_du_Maroc_1971_-_003.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/R%C3%A9tromobile_2011_-_Citro%C3%ABn_SM_Rallye_du_Maroc_1971_-_003.jpg/250px-R%C3%A9tromobile_2011_-_Citro%C3%ABn_SM_Rallye_du_Maroc_1971_-_003.jpg" width="250" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/R%C3%A9tromobile_2011_-_Citro%C3%ABn_SM_Rallye_du_Maroc_1971_-_003.jpg/375px-R%C3%A9tromobile_2011_-_Citro%C3%ABn_SM_Rallye_du_Maroc_1971_-_003.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/R%C3%A9tromobile_2011_-_Citro%C3%ABn_SM_Rallye_du_Maroc_1971_-_003.jpg/500px-R%C3%A9tromobile_2011_-_Citro%C3%ABn_SM_Rallye_du_Maroc_1971_-_003.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4752" data-file-height="3168" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:R%C3%A9tromobile_2011_-_Citro%C3%ABn_SM_Rallye_du_Maroc_1971_-_003.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
1971 <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_SM" title="Citroën SM">Citroën SM</a> that won <a href="/wiki/Rallye_du_Maroc" title="Rallye du Maroc">Rallye du Maroc</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Citroën vehicles were entered in endurance <a href="/wiki/Rallying" title="Rallying">rally driving</a> events beginning in 1956, with the introduction of the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS" title="Citroën DS">DS</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-61">[61]</a></sup> The brand was successful and won many key events over a decades long period, with what was essentially the same production car design.</p>
<div>

<tr>
<td style="width: 33.33%;text-align:left;vertical-align:top;">

</table>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Racing_the_2CV">Racing the 2CV</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Racing the 2CV">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Citroën discovered that while racing the uniquely slow <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_2CV" title="Citroën 2CV">2CV</a> against other cars made little sense, they could be interesting to watch racing against each other. Citroën Competitions sponsored three long distance competitions – Paris-Kaboul-Paris in 1970, Paris-Persepolis-Paris in 1972, and Raid Afrique in 1973.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup></p>
<p>Enthusiasts carried on the tradition with <i>2CV Cross</i> – a group of 2CV's racing around a dirt track – a sport that continues today.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rebuilding_the_competition_group">Rebuilding the competition group</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Rebuilding the competition group">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The Citroën Competitions division was impacted negatively by the firm's 1974 bankruptcy.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_61-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-61">[61]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_61-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-61">[61]</a></sup></p>
<p>Competitive rallying was also changing – away from standard production cars to specially developed low volume models. In response to the entry of the competitive short wheel base <a href="/wiki/Group_B" title="Group B">Group B</a> <a href="/wiki/4_wheel_drive" class="mw-redirect" title="4 wheel drive">4 wheel drive</a> <a href="/wiki/Audi_Quattro" title="Audi Quattro">Audi Quattro</a> into rallying, Citroën developed the heavily modified <a href="/wiki/Group_B" title="Group B">Group B</a> <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_BX#4TC" title="Citroën BX">Citroën BX 4TC</a> in <a href="/wiki/1986_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="1986 World Rally Championship season">1986</a>.</p>
<p>The team returned successfully with the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_ZX" title="Citroën ZX">Citroën ZX</a> Rally Raid to win the <a href="/wiki/Rally_Raid" class="mw-redirect" title="Rally Raid">Rally Raid</a> Manufacturer's Championship five times (1993, 1994, 1995, 1996, and 1997) with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pierre_Lartigue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pierre Lartigue (page does not exist)">Pierre Lartigue</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ari_Vatanen" title="Ari Vatanen">Ari Vatanen</a>. Citroën Racing won the <a href="/wiki/Dakar_Rally" title="Dakar Rally">Dakar Rally</a> four times, in 1991, continuing the serial of four victories of <a href="/wiki/Peugeot#Motorsport" title="Peugeot">Peugeot sport</a>, and then again in 1994, 1995, and 1996.</p>
<p>From 2001, the Citroën Racing team returned successfully to the <a href="/wiki/World_Rally_Championship" title="World Rally Championship">World Rally Championship</a>, winning eight times the <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Rally_Championship_Constructors%27_Champions" class="mw-redirect" title="List of World Rally Championship Constructors' Champions">Manufacturer's Title</a>, continuing the serial of three WRC Championships victories of <a href="/wiki/Peugeot#Motorsport" title="Peugeot">Peugeot sport</a>, in <a href="/wiki/2003_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2003 World Rally Championship season">2003</a>, <a href="/wiki/2004_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2004 World Rally Championship season">2004</a>, <a href="/wiki/2005_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2005 World Rally Championship season">2005</a>, <a href="/wiki/2008_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2008 World Rally Championship season">2008</a>, <a href="/wiki/2009_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2009 World Rally Championship season">2009</a>, <a href="/wiki/2010_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2010 World Rally Championship season">2010</a>, <a href="/wiki/2011_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2011 World Rally Championship season">2011</a> and <a href="/wiki/2012_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2012 World Rally Championship season">2012</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_World_Rally_Team" title="Citroën World Rally Team">Citroën WRC Team</a> pilot <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A9bastien_Loeb" title="Sébastien Loeb">Sébastien Loeb</a> also won nine <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Rally_Championship_Drivers%27_Champions" class="mw-redirect" title="List of World Rally Championship Drivers' Champions">Drivers' Championships</a>. In 2004, 2005, and <a href="/wiki/2006_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2006 World Rally Championship season">2006</a>, the French pilot won the <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Rally_Championship_Drivers%27_Champions" class="mw-redirect" title="List of World Rally Championship Drivers' Champions">Drivers' Championship</a>, driving the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Xsara" title="Citroën Xsara">Citroën Xsara WRC</a>, in 2007, 2008, 2009 and 2010 with the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C4" title="Citroën C4">Citroën C4 WRC</a>, and in 2011 and 2012 with the new <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS3" class="mw-redirect" title="Citroën DS3">Citroën DS3 WRC</a>.</p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_World_Rally_Team" title="Citroën World Rally Team">Citroën World Rally Team</a> has a record of 97 victories in the World Rally Championship. In 2014, Citroën was the automaker that won the most world championship titles: 14 World Champion titles in 15 appearances. Citroën won the World Rally Raid Championship 5 times, the World Rally Championship 8 times, and the World Touring Car Championship in its first participation.</p>
<div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:697px;max-width:697px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:267px;max-width:267px">

</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:212px;max-width:212px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Festival_automobile_international_2014_-_Citro%C3%ABn_C-Elys%C3%A9e_-_005.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Festival_automobile_international_2014_-_Citro%C3%ABn_C-Elys%C3%A9e_-_005.jpg/210px-Festival_automobile_international_2014_-_Citro%C3%ABn_C-Elys%C3%A9e_-_005.jpg" width="210" height="140" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Festival_automobile_international_2014_-_Citro%C3%ABn_C-Elys%C3%A9e_-_005.jpg/315px-Festival_automobile_international_2014_-_Citro%C3%ABn_C-Elys%C3%A9e_-_005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Festival_automobile_international_2014_-_Citro%C3%ABn_C-Elys%C3%A9e_-_005.jpg/420px-Festival_automobile_international_2014_-_Citro%C3%ABn_C-Elys%C3%A9e_-_005.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C-Elys%C3%A9e" class="mw-redirect" title="Citroën C-Elysée">Citroën C-Elysée WTCC</a> on display</div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
</div>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="New_competition_division_for_touring_cars">New competition division for touring cars</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: New competition division for touring cars">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 2013, Citroën Racing created a new sub-division, the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_World_Touring_Car_Team" title="Citroën World Touring Car Team">Citroën World Touring Car Team</a>, in order to attempt the 2014 <a href="/wiki/World_Touring_Car_Championship" title="World Touring Car Championship">World Touring Car Championship</a>. The name <i>Citroën C-Elysée WTCC</i> has been chosen for the race car running in this world competition. It was developed in a few months, thanks to the experience of the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_World_Rally_Team" title="Citroën World Rally Team">Citroën World Rally Team</a>. Citroën revealed a thirty-minute film on its Internet channel, to show the different steps to the C-Elysée project development&#160;: Projet M43 WTCC, Citroën WTCC 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_World_Touring_Car_Team" title="Citroën World Touring Car Team">Citroën World Touring Car Team</a> won fourteen victories out of the fifteen first races of the <a href="/wiki/2014_World_Touring_Car_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 World Touring Car Championship season">2014 WTCC season</a>, in spite of the handicap of the 60&#160;kg Compensation Weight put to the leading cars. The <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_World_Touring_Car_Team" title="Citroën World Touring Car Team">Citroën/Total WTCC Team</a> won the <i>Manufacturer's WTCC Championship</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> 5 races before the end of the season, after the <a href="/wiki/2014_FIA_WTCC_Race_of_China,_Shanghai" title="2014 FIA WTCC Race of China, Shanghai">2014 Shanghai</a> race, where Citroën won first, second, third and fourth place, and recorded the fastest lap time. The <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_World_Touring_Car_Team" title="Citroën World Touring Car Team">Citroën World Touring Car Team</a> pilots also got the three first ranks of the Drivers' World Touring Car Championship.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Concept_cars">Concept cars</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Concept cars">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Citro%C3%ABn_Hypnos_002.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Citro%C3%ABn_Hypnos_002.jpg/220px-Citro%C3%ABn_Hypnos_002.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Citro%C3%ABn_Hypnos_002.jpg/330px-Citro%C3%ABn_Hypnos_002.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Citro%C3%ABn_Hypnos_002.jpg/440px-Citro%C3%ABn_Hypnos_002.jpg 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="540" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Citro%C3%ABn_Hypnos_002.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Hypnos" title="Citroën Hypnos">Citroën Hypnos</a> (2008)</div>
</div>
</div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_concept_cars" title="Citroën concept cars">Citroën concept cars</a></div>
<p>Citroën has produced numerous <a href="/wiki/Concept_cars" class="mw-redirect" title="Concept cars">concept cars</a> over the decades, previewing future design trends or technologies. Notable concepts include the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Karin" title="Citroën Karin">Citroën Karin</a> (1980), <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Activa" title="Citroën Activa">Citroën Activa</a> (1988), <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C-M%C3%A9tisse" title="Citroën C-Métisse">Citroën C-Métisse</a> (2006), <a href="/wiki/GT_by_Citro%C3%ABn" title="GT by Citroën">GT by Citroën</a> (2008) and <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Survolt" title="Citroën Survolt">Citroën Survolt</a> (2010).</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Logo">Logo</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Logo">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Engrenages_-_85.488_-.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Engrenages - 85.488 -.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Engrenages_-_85.488_-.jpg/150px-Engrenages_-_85.488_-.jpg" width="150" height="215" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Engrenages_-_85.488_-.jpg/225px-Engrenages_-_85.488_-.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Engrenages_-_85.488_-.jpg/300px-Engrenages_-_85.488_-.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1009" data-file-height="1444" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Engrenages_-_85.488_-.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The origin of the logo may be traced back to a trip made by the 22-year-old André Citroën to <a href="/wiki/%C5%81%C3%B3d%C5%BA" title="Łódź">Łódź</a> city, <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a>, where he discovered an innovative design for a <a href="/wiki/Chevron_(insignia)" title="Chevron (insignia)">chevron</a>-shaped <a href="/wiki/Gear" title="Gear">gear</a> used in <a href="/wiki/Milling_(grinding)" class="mw-redirect" title="Milling (grinding)">milling</a>. He bought the patent for its application in steel. Mechanically a gear with helical teeth produces an axial force. By adding a second helical gear in opposition, this force is cancelled. The two chevrons of the logo represent the intermeshing contact of the two.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup></p>
<p>The presentation of the logo has evolved over time. Before the war, it was rendered in yellow on a blue background. After the war, the chevrons became more subtle <a href="/wiki/Herringbone_gear" title="Herringbone gear">herringbones</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> usually on a white background. With the company searching for a new image during the 1980s, the logo became white on red to give an impression of dynamism, emphasized by publicity slogan.</p>
<p>In February 2009 Citroën launched a new brand identity to celebrate its 90th anniversary, replacing the 1977 design. The new logo was designed by Landor Associates<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> — a 3D metallic variation of the double chevron logo accompanied by a new font for the Citroën name and the new slogan "Créative Technologie". A TV campaign reminiscing over <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7009284018400000000♠</span>90&#160;years</span> of Citroën was commissioned to announce the new identity to the public.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> The new look is currently being rolled out to dealers globally and is expected to take three to five years.</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional"></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Factories">Factories</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Factories">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul>
<li>Argentina (<a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>): Berlingo First</li>
<li>Argentina (<a href="/wiki/Villa_Bosch" title="Villa Bosch">Villa Bosch</a>): C4, C4 L</li>
<li>Brazil (<a href="/wiki/Porto_Real" title="Porto Real">Porto Real</a>): C3, C3 Picasso</li>
<li>France (<a href="/wiki/Mulhouse" title="Mulhouse">Mulhouse</a>): C4, DS4</li>
<li>France (<a href="/wiki/Poissy" title="Poissy">Poissy</a>): C3, DS3</li>
<li>France (<a href="/wiki/Aulnay-sous-Bois" title="Aulnay-sous-Bois">Aulnay</a>): C3 (closing 2014)<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup></li>
<li>France (<a href="/wiki/Sochaux" title="Sochaux">Sochaux</a>): DS5</li>
<li>France (<a href="/wiki/Rennes" title="Rennes">Rennes</a>): <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_C5" title="Citroën C5">C5</a></li>
<li>Portugal (<a href="/wiki/Mangualde" title="Mangualde">Mangualde</a>): Berlingo First</li>
<li>Slovakia (<a href="/wiki/Trnava" title="Trnava">Trnava</a>): C3 Picasso, new C3 (2016)</li>
<li>Spain (<a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a>): C3, C4 Cactus</li>
<li>Spain (<a href="/wiki/Vigo_PSA_Factory" class="mw-redirect" title="Vigo PSA Factory">Vigo</a>): Berlingo First, Berlingo, C4 Picasso / C4 Grand Picasso, C-Elysee</li>
<li>Turkey (<a href="/wiki/Bursa" title="Bursa">Bursa</a>): Nemo</li>
</ul>
<p>Some joint venture models are manufactured in third party or joint venture factories, including the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>China (<a href="/wiki/Shenzhen" title="Shenzhen">Shenzhen</a>), <a href="/wiki/Chang%27an_Automobile_Group" class="mw-redirect" title="Chang'an Automobile Group">Chang'an</a> PSA joint venture: <a href="/wiki/DS_5LS" title="DS 5LS">DS 5LS</a> and <a href="/wiki/DS_6WR" class="mw-redirect" title="DS 6WR">DS 6WR</a></li>
<li>China (<a href="/wiki/Wuhan" title="Wuhan">Wuhan</a>), <a href="/wiki/Dongfeng_Peugeot-Citro%C3%ABn_Automobile" class="mw-redirect" title="Dongfeng Peugeot-Citroën Automobile">Dongfeng Peugeot-Citroën Automobile</a> joint venture: C-Elysee, C3 L, Xsara Picasso, C4 L, C5</li>
<li>Czech Republic (<a href="/wiki/Kol%C3%ADn" title="Kolín">Kolín</a>), Toyota/PSA joint venture: C1</li>
<li>France (<a href="/wiki/Valenciennes" title="Valenciennes">Valenciennes</a>) PSA/Fiat joint venture <a href="/wiki/Sevel_Nord" class="mw-redirect" title="Sevel Nord">Sevel Nord</a>: <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Jumpy" title="Citroën Jumpy">Citroën Jumpy</a>/Dispatch</li>
<li>Italy (<a href="/wiki/Val_di_Sangro" class="mw-redirect" title="Val di Sangro">Val di Sangro</a>), PSA/Fiat joint venture <a href="/wiki/Sevel_Sud" class="mw-redirect" title="Sevel Sud">Sevel Sud</a>: Jumper/Relay</li>
<li>Japan (<a href="/wiki/Kurashiki,_Okayama" title="Kurashiki, Okayama">Mizushima</a>). <a href="/wiki/Mitsubishi_Motors" title="Mitsubishi Motors">Mitsubishi Motors</a> plant: C-Zero</li>
<li>Russia (<a href="/wiki/Kaluga" title="Kaluga">Kaluga</a>), PSA/Mitsubishi joint venture&#160;: C4, C-Crosser</li>
<li>Turkey, <a href="/wiki/Karsan" title="Karsan">Karsan</a> plant: Berlingo</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Current_product_lineup">Current product lineup</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Current product lineup">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Citro.C3.ABn">Citroën</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Citroën">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>

<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
<div style="width: 155px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;">

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dongfeng_Peugeot-Citro.C3.ABn_.28joint_venture.29">Dongfeng Peugeot-Citroën (joint venture)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Citro%C3%ABn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Dongfeng Peugeot-Citroën (joint venture)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
<div style="width: 155px">

<li id="cite_note-40"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-40">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://businesstech.co.za/news/motoring/146509/french-car-maker-to-shut-up-shop-in-south-africa/">"French car maker to shut up shop in South Africa"</a>. <i>businesstech.co.za</i>. <li id="cite_note-41"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-41">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.iol.co.za/motoring/brakes-put-on-citron-sales-in-sa-7120952">"Brakes put on Citroën sales in SA"</a>. <i>iol.co.za</i>. <li id="cite_note-60"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-60">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Chris Nagy (2012-11-14). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.automoblog.net/2012/11/14/tesla-model-s-named-car-of-the-year-by-motor-trend/">"Powered Up: Tesla Model S Named 'Car of the Year' By Motor Trend"</a>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2016-07-16</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACitro%C3%ABn&amp;rft.au=Chris+Nagy&amp;rft.btitle=Powered+Up%3A+Tesla+Model+S+Named+%27Car+of+the+Year%27+By+Motor+Trend&amp;rft.date=2012-11-14&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.automoblog.net%2F2012%2F11%2F14%2Ftesla-model-s-named-car-of-the-year-by-motor-trend%2F&amp;rft.pub=Automoblog.net&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-ReferenceA-61"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-ReferenceA_61-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ReferenceA_61-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ReferenceA_61-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.citroenet.org.uk/sport/ds-rally-cars-01.html">"Citroën DS in sport"</a>. Citroenet.org.uk. 2000-06-10<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2016-07-16</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACitro%C3%ABn&amp;rft.btitle=Citro%C3%ABn+DS+in+sport&amp;rft.date=2000-06-10&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.citroenet.org.uk%2Fsport%2Fds-rally-cars-01.html&amp;rft.pub=Citroenet.org.uk&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>

<li id="cite_note-63"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-63">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://raid2cv-cinoche.blogspot.com">http://raid2cv-cinoche.blogspot.com</a> in French</span></li>

<tr>
<th scope="row" class="navbox-group">Historic models</th>
<td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
<div style="padding:0em 0.25em"></div>
<table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0">
<tr>
<th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="padding-left:0;padding-right:0;">
<div style="padding:0em 0.75em;">Cars</div>

<div role="navigation" class="navbox" aria-labelledby="Groupe_PSA.2C_owner_of_the_Peugeot.2C_Citro.C3.ABn.2C_DS_Automobiles.2C_Opel.2C_Vauxhall_and_Ambassador_brands" style="padding:3px">
<table class="nowraplinks collapsible autocollapse navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit">
<tr>
<th scope="col" class="navbox-title" colspan="3">
<div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
<ul>
<li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Groupe_PSA" title="Template:Groupe PSA"><abbr title="View this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;">v</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Groupe_PSA" title="Template talk:Groupe PSA"><abbr title="Discuss this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;">t</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Groupe_PSA&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;">e</abbr></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<div id="Groupe_PSA.2C_owner_of_the_Peugeot.2C_Citro.C3.ABn.2C_DS_Automobiles.2C_Opel.2C_Vauxhall_and_Ambassador_brands" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Groupe_PSA" title="Groupe PSA">Groupe PSA</a>, owner of the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot" title="Peugeot">Peugeot</a>, <strong class="selflink">Citroën</strong>, <a href="/wiki/DS_Automobiles" title="DS Automobiles">DS Automobiles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Opel" title="Opel">Opel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vauxhall_Motors" title="Vauxhall Motors">Vauxhall</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hindustan_Ambassador" title="Hindustan Ambassador">Ambassador</a> brands</div>
</th>
</tr>
<tr style="height:2px">
<td colspan="2"></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" class="navbox-group">Current Automobile Marques</th>
<td class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
<div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot" title="Peugeot">Peugeot</a></li>
<li><strong class="selflink">Citroën</strong></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/DS_Automobiles" title="DS Automobiles">DS Automobiles</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Opel" title="Opel">Opel</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Vauxhall_Motors" title="Vauxhall Motors">Vauxhall</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Hindustan_Ambassador" title="Hindustan Ambassador">Ambassador</a></li>
</ul>
<p><i>Negotiations pending</i>&#160;:</p>
<ul>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/PROTON_Holdings" title="PROTON Holdings">Proton</a></i></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Lotus_Cars" title="Lotus Cars">Lotus</a></i></li>
</ul>
</div>
</td>
<td class="navbox-image" rowspan="25" style="width:0%;padding:0px 0px 0px 2px">

<li><a href="/wiki/PSA_XUD_engine" class="mw-redirect" title="PSA XUD engine">PSA XUD engine</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="height:2px">
<td colspan="2"></td>
</tr>
<tr>

<h3>
